item.title: Munged
item.content:encoded:
Munge: /muhnj/, vt.

  1. [derogatory] To imperfectly transform information.
  2. A comprehensive rewrite of a routine, data structure or the whole program.
  3. To modify data in some way the speaker doesn't need to go into right now or cannot describe succinctly (compare mumble).
  4. To add spamblock to an email address.

This term is often confused with mung, which probably was derived from it. However, it also appears the word munge was in common use in Scotland in the 1940s, and in Yorkshire in the 1950s, as a verb, meaning to munch up into a masticated mess, and as a noun, meaning the result of munging something up (the parallel with the kluge/kludge pair is amusing). The OED reports “munge” as an archaic verb meaning “to wipe (a person's nose)”.

from The Jargon File, v4.4.8

item.title: Going Native or Going Somewhere Else
item.content:encoded:
My Squarespace subscription is up towards the end of April.  So I'm playing around with it to see if I want to stick around here.  The new template is called "Native".  It is cleaner than the old "Bedford" template, but still obviously way more focused on the visuals than I feel Munged.Org needs to be.  Pictures can go up over on WookPhoto.

Some things that Squarespace made easy: The gallery of DC25 photos was pretty easy to put up and looked good. Adding any pictures has been pretty easy, and includes basic photo editing controls to make them look like I want. Easy integration to YouTube and Vimeo videos for the Phantom.  But it isn't perfect. The link tool will show some of the content of this site to link to, but not blog pages.  I had to save this as draft, go find the link to the DC25 gallery, then edit this file again to paste it in. Hope it works the way I formatting the link. Edit: Nope!

Where else would I go?

I'm currently testing moving the site over to GitHub Pages.  It also has some interesting implications about security and accessibility that may be considered "features", or not. For one thing, because I'm not paying for Github, the source of the site is in a public repository. Everything is visible: page templates and formatting code, plus the content source.

This means that all y'all could clone the repo, fix things, and send me pull requests to include your fixes on my site. What would you change?  Spelling. Formatting. Site changes. Fact checking. Adding interesting links. Whatever you are willing to spend the time to do to make the site better. It is my option to include any changes, but it is an interesting idea.

There's also an issue tracker I'm using to remind myself of things I want to do, and a wiki that can be used for off-site collaboration. The wiki is intended for documentation, and I have to admit the idea of my blog having "documentation" amuses me.

The downside is that it isn't really easier than Squarespace. The repository has to be cloned to my computers, and edited locally.  Changes are version controlled, which is nice, but live locally until synced with the main repo on GitHub.  If I forget to sync, I could take the laptop and not have the most recent changes that live on the desk machine.

I'm using GitHub and git, for the first time, so still kind of feeling my way along. I GPG signed a tag (version release) last night at a completely inappropriate spot in the development of the site for example.  Tho really, that was just to see what it looked like. I might, once I get everything the way I want it, blow away the repo and re-create it from files saved locally.

If I move over there, I'll make sure to import all the posts from here as well.  There aren't that many posts here, it will be easy.  I might, if I end up with the energy and interest, import the really old site from the Moveable Type days.  Sadly, the WordPress site is gone.  But there wasn't much there anyway.

It is very interesting, but will kind of be a lot of work for nothing if I stay here. Them's the breaks, I guess. Or maybe I'll give Textpattern a try again.
item.dc:creator: squarespace@munged.org

item.title: New iPhone and iPad
item.content:encoded:
The plan is to get upgraded to current iPhone, and iPad.  I have a new iPhone 6, 128 Gig on Verizon.  Those phones are hard to find out in the wild, but for assorted reasons I couldn't order it from the Apple Web Store.  I found one in Albuquerque last week.  I did order an engraved iPad Air 2 from the Apple Web Store, and it was waiting for me when I got home yesterday.

I just need to get Ally an iPhone, and then the current upgrade cycle is complete. I should actually be able to get her phone thru the Web Store.

Ally was already on Verizon, and I have switched to it.  I have mixed feelings about this. It is really nice to be able to use my personal phone in my house. AT&T didn't serve this area very well, and I had a lot of dropped calls.  My work mobile phone is on Verizon, because I had this same problem in DUMBO before I moved to the woods of Carrboro.

Verizon has good coverage, and they use CDMA, so the call quality will be good.  But they are just evil incarnate.  I switched from Sprint to Verizon back in the day, so I could get a Motorola Razer flip phone. It would access the internet, and I even tried it once.  There was a "landing page" that indicated if you proceeded, you'd be using the internet and would be charged for it.  What that landing page didn't say was that it itself was on the internet, and you were already being charged for using it.  This sleazy move got Verizon slapped with a lawsuit, which they lost.

So.  The ability to use my phone from home if I so choose.  Or not supporting evil asshole corporations.  Kind of an ugly choice.

After a few years of shitty "service" on AT&T's part, I am done. I am on Verizon. I could have gone with Sprint, but I had an iPad Air 2 that I returned, and had it on Sprint for a while, and didn't have good coverage from home with them either.

I still feel queasy about this choice tho.
item.dc:creator: squarespace@munged.org

item.title: Categories
item.content:encoded:
I can assign categories to posts.  Problem is, I'd rather have one set of categories, and use them forever more, with the occational addition as new things come up.

Or, I'd rather have a small set where each is broad enough that I won't ever need any new ones.

Or....

Sigh.  Crap.

There are like 4 posts on this blog, and already I am running into things that should only bother me when I realize I have 200+ posts in the category "Opinion" and another couple hundred in "Pontification".  Both categories being the same thing in my mind.

This is partially a case of having a feature and being determined to use it no matter how useful it is.  As a tech support goon, I see the CONSTANTLY in other people.  You'd think after seeing the evil it causes, I'd be imune.  But I like my toys too, which is basically what a feature is.

So, ideas.

  • "Show", "Tell"
  • "YMMV", "IANAL", "ROFL", "OMW", "IIRC", etc
  • "<A>", "<BLOCKQUOTE>", "<LI>", etc
  • "Car", "Life", "Event", "Opinion", "Site"

Right now, as I write this, I'm leaning towards the internet slang abreviations.  Damn Brett Glass for taking ymmv.com back in the 90's and not updating the content on it in over 16 years.  That's just mean.
item.dc:creator: squarespace@munged.org

item.title: Mirror Mystery
item.content:encoded:
My car has power side mirrors, as most do these days.  You set them with a control in the car, and when you use the driver memory function their position is recorded in the memory setting.

Another feature of some modern cars is that when you put the car in reverse, the passenger side mirror will move and point down at the side of the car, so that when parallel parking, you can see where you are in relation to the curb.

My car does this, but not all the time.  In fact, it didn't do it for the first two years I owned it.  Then one day, it did.  And it did it for a few months, until it went in for service recently.  Then it didn't.  But today, it suddenly is doing it again.

I think I've figured it out.

Ally drove it last night, so of course she screwed up the seats and mirrors.  When I drove it after that, I used the memory buttons to return everything to my settings.  When I came home from lunch today I noticed the mirror pointed down again while I was backing into the driveway.

So yeah, I could probably read the manual to figure this out, but who reads anymore?  Seriously.

I don't think the car can remember a random mirror position.  So if the mirror isn't at a memory setting, it won't move down in reverse because it doesn't know where to move back to when it is done.

Kinda cheesy, really, for an expensive car.  You'd think it could remember something like this.  But I have to remember, while there is a lot about my car that is nice, it is still the lowest tier in the product linup.  Or was when I bought it.  Now the bottom Audi rung in the US is the A3.
item.dc:creator: squarespace@munged.org

item.title: Science Isn't Truth
item.content:encoded:
It sucks when talented science communicators get something wrong.  Neil DeGrass Tyson, in his Cosmos series, says over and over that "science is the search for truth".  It bothered me when he I heard that, because I think there are truths that aren't discoverable via science.  For example, despite lots of research on altruism, "be nice to each other" isn't something you will arrive at via science.  (Tho you can get close.)

http://theweek.com/article/index/268360/how-our-botched-understanding-of-science-ruins-everything
item.dc:creator: squarespace@munged.org

item.title: The Sharing Economy Really Isn't
item.content:encoded:
Supposedly, if you listen to the nut-jobs in Silicon Valley, you will know that we are entering the "sharing economy", whereby people with more than they need, "share" it with other people.  The companies are

The idea is this: you have something but either won't be using it, or want to share it with others.  You do this out of the goodness of your heart, I think.  You own a house, and have a spare room, so you share it.  Own a car? Going across town and have a seat open? Share it.  Remember, you aren't renting or playing taxi, you are "SHARING".

Bullshit.

We've had carpooling, "ride boards" at schools, and other means of finding a ride to share forever. People have taken in boarders forever, in fact back in the early 20th century it was pretty common. People have owned houses on the New Jersey shore, and pretty much all along the eastern seaboard, forever, and have rented them out during the summer months to cover costs of owning a second house too far away from work to commute to every day.

Now, suddenly these activities are "sharing"?  No.

Well, yes they are, but they are sharing the same way a hotel "shares" a room with you, or a taxi driver "shares" a ride with you. They provide a service and you pay them money.  This really isn't new.

The leap these companies have made, is not about sharing.  It is about providing access to the customer base.

When I was a kid, if you had a car and wanted to carpool, you had to somehow find someone to carpool with. But this only worked because you could take the time, and it could be set up way in advance. Finding someone who would kick in a few bucks for a long trip across town an hour from now was basically impossible.  So didn't happen much. 

What Airbnb, Uber, Lyft, and others have done, is not made sharing possible, they've made it easy. AirBNB is a hotel room booking company.  Uber and Lyft are dispatch companies.  The difference between them and the companies that existed is that of lowering the barriers to access.  Both for the landlord/driver, and renter/rider.

Ten years ago, if you wanted to pick up people in your car, you had to sign up with a taxi company, get a commercial license, and put the equipment in your car to process payments. You weren't going to do this just to drive some shlub to the mall every now and then. Uber and Lyft will sign you up as driver or a rider if you have a smartphone and fill out a form on a web site.  They will handle the payment.  If that's all it takes to drive that shlub to the mall, then why the hell not.

This is a revolution, but not the one the proponents of "sharing" would have you believe it is.  These companies allow much easier access to both the providers and customers than was possible before.

Is this good?  Yes, I think it is.  But sharing isn't new.  The ease of access to the customer base is new.

Thus, the "Access Economy".
item.dc:creator: squarespace@munged.org

item.title: iPad Air 2 Notes
item.content:encoded:
Today I bought myself an iPad Air 2.  I'll update this over time with my impressions, comments, rants, and whatever else about this device.

First off, this thing is thin and light. So light, I have to wonder if I can trust it to last. My joke has been that it is so light that I'm finding it hard to take seriously. Like a grown woman with a little-girl voice.

I got Apple's "Smart Case" for it aswell.  I already hate it. But in my experience, I'd hate all the alternatives even more. The only case I ever liked was the very first one Apple ever made for the iPad 1.  It had cover with one fold in it, and if you tucked it into a flap on the back, you could stand it up or set it down to have it inclined towards you.  The current tri-fold, magnetized, bullshit isn't nearly as stable, reliable, or easy to handle.  That first one was sturdy enough to provide a handle of sorts for people like me with over-sized hands, new ones fail miserably that way.

Touch ID: LOVE IT.  It hasn't failed to unlock the device for the finger I have stored it it.  It hasn't opened for any other finger I've tried.  I've also got 1Password, the password manager I use, set up to accept it too, which is handy.

I didn't restore from my previous iPad, so I'm setting this one up by hand. I wanted to start fresh to leave behind the all the stuff I don't use that might be on the other one.  So far, this process has gone about as expected. It does take some time to run thru everything, but I knew that.  Other than that I won't comment on this process, unless as some time it has a problem.

I thought you were supposed to be able to use Apple Pay on the Air 2, but it doesn't have the passbook app, so I guess not.  Probably can use
item.dc:creator: squarespace@munged.org

item.title: About Munged and Wookie
item.content:encoded:
Who Am I?

My nickname is Wookie.  It is a college nickname, the details are long and boring.  It is what most people call me, outside of family.

Other than that, I'm just a guy that can afford an account with Squarespace.  I've blogged in the past, and am going to see what happens if I do so again.

What Is Going On Here?

This is just a place to type words that shows up (sometimes) where everyone in the world can see them. Anything could show up here: personal observations, opinions, incoherent swearing, links to stuff I find interesting, or whatever.

"Incoherent Swearing"?

I'm a potty-mouth.  I have opinions.  Sometimes, those two things collide in my brain and the results show up here.

Wook Elsewhere

I spent a while looking at some other, lesser-known, social networks.  I also have accounts on some more-known social networks. Here is the list of the ones I remember joining:

  • Wookman on Facebook
  • @wookman on Twitter
  • @wook on Ello
  • @wook on Gnusocial via quitter.no
  • wook@diasp.org on Diaspora via the diasp.org pod
  • &wook on Bubblews
  • wook.cupcake.is on Tent via Cupcake
  • wook@fmrl.me on Ephemeral Me, which is a pump.io server

item.title: Damnit!
item.content:encoded: You broke it, you now have to buy both pieces.
